content.raw:
we can have our own `computeBoundingBox` function that does something similar to threejs's  Box3.setFromObject function. The logic is mainly here:
https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/master/src/math/Box3.js#L207

It traverses through all children of the object when computing bounding box so in our case we'll just skip child objects that are visualizations
content.html:
we can have our own computeBoundingBox function that does something similar to threejs's Box3.setFromObject function. The logic is mainly here: https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/master/src/math/Box3.js#L207

It traverses through all children of the object when computing bounding box so in our case we'll just skip child objects that are visualizations

content.raw: So we don't use the `threejs`  `Box3.setFromObject` and make out own  `expandByObject`  function and customize it, am I right ?
content.html: So we don't use the threejs Box3.setFromObject and make out own expandByObject function and customize it, am I right ?

content.raw: yes that's right
content.html: yes that's right

content.raw:
Thanks, Done.

content.html:
Thanks, Done.

I'll also ticket an issue at threejs repo, they could add a feature something like that

content.raw: I'm reviewing your changes in [e7fe9f4](https://bitbucket.org/mohamd_ayman/gzweb/commits/e7fe9f4f31e98237f4ff253bea286047f180d7cf) where you modified threejs directly. To be clear, the original idea I was proposing is to add our own `computeBoundingBox` function in gzscene.js. Instead of calling `box.setFromObject(model)` [in this line](https://bitbucket.org/mohamd_ayman/gzweb/src/85ab129b73e0c0faacc62e65beb095ea9cf59877/gz3d/src/gzscene.js?fileviewer=file-view-default#gzscene.js-1925), we would be doing something like `var box = this.computeBoundingBox(model)`. In our `computeBoundingBox` function, that's where we check and ignore inertial visuals. Hope that makes sense.
content.html: I'm reviewing your changes in e7fe9f4 where you modified threejs directly. To be clear, the original idea I was proposing is to add our own computeBoundingBox function in gzscene.js. Instead of calling box.setFromObject(model) in this line, we would be doing something like var box = this.computeBoundingBox(model). In our computeBoundingBox function, that's where we check and ignore inertial visuals. Hope that makes sense.

content.raw: Yeah makes sense, I was actually not sure if modifying the `threejs` directly was a good idea, but it was sure easy :D
content.html: Yeah makes sense, I was actually not sure if modifying the threejs directly was a good idea, but it was sure easy :D

content.raw: Added a `setFromObject`  function to `gzscene`  and added two tests for it.
content.html: Added a setFromObject function to gzscene and added two tests for it.

content.raw:
Sorry, I always come to point out corner cases :sweat_smile: 

The `simple_arm` model is one of the few models in the database which has a ~~[rotation on the inertial pose](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_models/src/ca22037469dcc6acdb568de11e322bfadf256d0e/simple_arm/model.sdf?fileviewer=file-view-default#model.sdf-125)~~ **off-diagonal term in the inertia matrix**. It looks like it isn't being taken into account, note on gzclient on the right how the box is slightly rotated:

![inertiaclients.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/r77Gja/images/1806436023-inertiaclients.png)
content.html:
Sorry, I always come to point out corner cases

The simple_arm model is one of the few models in the database which has a rotation on the inertial pose off-diagonal term in the inertia matrix. It looks like it isn't being taken into account, note on gzclient on the right how the box is slightly rotated:

content.raw:
This makes sense.

I actually found out that I didn't multiply the box rotation with the inertial rotation like you did in this line 

``` c++
    // Apply additional rotation by boxRot
    this->Load(ignition::math::Pose3d(xyz, q * boxRot), boxScale);
```

Yeah you really are a good tester :sweat_smile:

Thanks for noticing that.
content.html:
This makes sense.

I actually found out that I didn't multiply the box rotation with the inertial rotation like you did in this line 

    // Apply additional rotation by boxRot
    this->Load(ignition::math::Pose3d(xyz, q * boxRot), boxScale);

Yeah you really are a good tester

Thanks for noticing that.


content.raw:
Ahh sorry, the rotation isn't because of the pose, it's because it has an [off-diagonal](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_models/src/ca22037469dcc6acdb568de11e322bfadf256d0e/simple_arm/model.sdf?fileviewer=file-view-default#model.sdf-132) element (ixz):

~~~
        <inertia>
          <ixx>0.031</ixx>
          <ixy>0</ixy>
          <ixz>0.005</ixz>
          <iyy>0.07275</iyy>
          <iyz>0</iyz>
          <izz>0.04475</izz>
        </inertia>
~~~
content.html:
Ahh sorry, the rotation isn't because of the pose, it's because it has an off-diagonal element (ixz):

        <inertia>
          <ixx>0.031</ixx>
          <ixy>0</ixy>
          <ixz>0.005</ixz>
          <iyy>0.07275</iyy>
          <iyz>0</iyz>
          <izz>0.04475</izz>
        </inertia>

content.raw: This feature was relatively recently added to [Gazebo 7](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2354/fix-inertiavisual-for-non-diagonal-inertia/diff#chg-gazebo/rendering/InertiaVisual.cc). I'm ok with ticketing an issue to tackle this later. Sorry about the confusion.
content.html: This feature was relatively recently added to Gazebo 7. I'm ok with ticketing an issue to tackle this later. Sorry about the confusion.

content.raw: I wonder if this test is really checking what it proposes itself to check. Since `obj` has no children, `scene.viewInertia` returns at `if (model.children.length === 0)`, which means the `view_inertia` event is not changing anything in the scene.
